text: From Paul, a slave of Christ Jesus, called to be an apostle, set apart for the gospel of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: This gospel he promised beforehand through his prophets in the holy scriptures,
speaker: Narrator

text: concerning his Son who was a descendant of David with reference to the flesh,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was appointed the Son-of-God-in-power according to the Holy Spirit by the resurrection from the dead, Jesus Christ our Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Through him we have received grace and our apostleship to bring about the obedience of faith among all the Gentiles on behalf of his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: You also are among them, called to belong to Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: To all those loved by God in Rome, called to be saints: Grace and peace to you from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ!
speaker: Narrator

text: First of all, I thank my God through Jesus Christ for all of you, because your faith is proclaimed throughout the whole world.
speaker: Narrator

text: For God, whom I serve in my spirit in the gospel of his Son, is my witness that I continually remember you
speaker: Narrator

text: and I always ask in my prayers, if perhaps now at last I may succeed in visiting you according to the will of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I long to see you, so that I may impart to you some spiritual gift to strengthen you,
speaker: Narrator

text: that is, that we may be mutually comforted by one another’s faith, both yours and mine.
speaker: Narrator

text: I do not want you to be unaware, brothers and sisters, that I often intended to come to you (and was prevented until now), so that I may have some fruit even among you, just as I already have among the rest of the Gentiles.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am a debtor both to the Greeks and to the barbarians, both to the wise and to the foolish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus I am eager also to preach the gospel to you who are in Rome.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I am not ashamed of the gospel, for it is God’s power for salvation to everyone who believes, to the Jew first and also to the Greek.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the righteousness of God is revealed in the gospel from faith to faith, just as it is written, “The righteous by faith will live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of people who suppress the truth by their unrighteousness,
speaker: Narrator

text: because what can be known about God is plain to them, because God has made it plain to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For since the creation of the world his invisible attributes—his eternal power and divine nature—have been clearly seen, because they are understood through what has been made. So people are without excuse.
speaker: Narrator

text: For although they knew God, they did not glorify him as God or give him thanks, but they became futile in their thoughts and their senseless hearts were darkened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Although they claimed to be wise, they became fools
speaker: Narrator

text: and exchanged the glory of the immortal God for an image resembling mortal human beings or birds or four-footed animals or reptiles.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore God gave them over in the desires of their hearts to impurity, to dishonor their bodies among themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: They exchanged the truth of God for a lie and worshiped and served the creation rather than the Creator, who is blessed forever! Amen.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason God gave them over to dishonorable passions. For their women exchanged the natural sexual relations for unnatural ones,
speaker: Narrator

text: and likewise the men also abandoned natural relations with women and were inflamed in their passions for one another. Men committed shameless acts with men and received in themselves the due penalty for their error.
speaker: Narrator

text: And just as they did not see fit to acknowledge God, God gave them over to a depraved mind, to do what should not be done.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are filled with every kind of unrighteousness, wickedness, covetousness, malice. They are rife with envy, murder, strife, deceit, hostility. They are gossips,
speaker: Narrator

text: slanderers, haters of God, insolent, arrogant, boastful, contrivers of all sorts of evil, disobedient to parents,
speaker: Narrator

text: senseless, covenant-breakers, heartless, ruthless.
speaker: Narrator

text: Although they fully know God’s righteous decree that those who practice such things deserve to die, they not only do them but also approve of those who practice them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore you are without excuse, whoever you are, when you judge someone else. For on whatever grounds you judge another, you condemn yourself, because you who judge practice the same things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now we know that God’s judgment is in accordance with truth against those who practice such things.
speaker: Narrator

text: And do you think, whoever you are, when you judge those who practice such things and yet do them yourself, that you will escape God’s judgment?
speaker: Narrator

text: Or do you have contempt for the wealth of his kindness, forbearance, and patience, and yet do not know that God’s kindness leads you to repentance?
speaker: Narrator

text: But because of your stubbornness and your unrepentant heart, you are storing up wrath for yourselves in the day of wrath, when God’s righteous judgment is revealed!
speaker: Narrator

text: He will reward each one according to his works:
speaker: Narrator

text: eternal life to those who by perseverance in good works seek glory and honor and immortality,
speaker: Narrator

text: but wrath and anger to those who live in selfish ambition and do not obey the truth but follow unrighteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: There will be affliction and distress on everyone who does evil, on the Jew first and also the Greek,
speaker: Narrator

text: but glory and honor and peace for everyone who does good, for the Jew first and also the Greek.
speaker: Narrator

text: For there is no partiality with God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all who have sinned apart from the law will also perish apart from the law, and all who have sinned under the law will be judged by the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it is not those who hear the law who are righteous before God, but those who do the law will be declared righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text: For whenever the Gentiles, who do not have the law, do by nature the things required by the law, these who do not have the law are a law to themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: They show that the work of the law is written in their hearts, as their conscience bears witness and their conflicting thoughts accuse or else defend them,
speaker: Narrator

text: on the day when God will judge the secrets of human hearts, according to my gospel through Christ Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you call yourself a Jew and rely on the law and boast of your relationship to God
speaker: Narrator

text: and know his will and approve the superior things because you receive instruction from the law,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if you are convinced that you yourself are a guide to the blind, a light to those who are in darkness,
speaker: Narrator

text: an educator of the senseless, a teacher of little children, because you have in the law the essential features of knowledge and of the truth—
speaker: Narrator

text: therefore you who teach someone else, do you not teach yourself? You who preach against stealing, do you steal?
speaker: Narrator

text: You who tell others not to commit adultery, do you commit adultery? You who abhor idols, do you rob temples?
speaker: Narrator

text: You who boast in the law dishonor God by transgressing the law!
speaker: Narrator

text: For just as it is written, “the name of God is being blasphemed among the Gentiles because of you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For circumcision has its value if you practice the law, but if you break the law, your circumcision has become uncircumcision.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore if the uncircumcised man obeys the righteous requirements of the law, will not his uncircumcision be regarded as circumcision?
speaker: Narrator

text: And the physically uncircumcised man, by keeping the law, will judge you to be the transgressor of the law, even though you have the letter and circumcision!
speaker: Narrator

text: For a person is not a Jew who is one outwardly, nor is circumcision something that is outward in the flesh,
speaker: Narrator

text: but someone is a Jew who is one inwardly, and circumcision is of the heart by the Spirit and not by the letter. This person’s praise is not from people but from God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore what advantage does the Jew have, or what is the value of circumcision?
speaker: Narrator

text: Actually, there are many advantages. First of all, the Jews were entrusted with the oracles of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then? If some were unfaithful, their unfaithfulness will not nullify God’s faithfulness, will it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Absolutely not! Let God be proven true, and every human being shown up as a liar, just as it is written: “so that you will be justified in your words and will prevail when you are judged.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But if our unrighteousness demonstrates the righteousness of God, what shall we say? The God who inflicts wrath is not unrighteous, is he? (I am speaking in human terms.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Absolutely not! For otherwise how could God judge the world?
speaker: Narrator

text: For if by my lie the truth of God enhances his glory, why am I still actually being judged as a sinner?
speaker: Narrator

text: And why not say, “Let us do evil so that good may come of it”?—as some who slander us allege that we say. (Their condemnation is deserved!)
speaker: Narrator

text: What then? Are we better off? Certainly not, for we have already charged that Jews and Greeks alike are all under sin,
speaker: Narrator

text:
just as it is written:
“There is no one righteous, not even one,
speaker: Narrator

text:
there is no one who understands,
there is no one who seeks God.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Their throats are open graves,
they deceive with their tongues,
the poison of asps is under their lips.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Their mouths are full of cursing and bitterness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Their feet are swift to shed blood,
speaker: Narrator

text: ruin and misery are in their paths,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the way of peace they have not known.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “There is no fear of God before their eyes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now we know that whatever the law says, it says to those who are under the law, so that every mouth may be silenced and the whole world may be held accountable to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For no one is declared righteous before him by the works of the law, for through the law comes the knowledge of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now apart from the law the righteousness of God (although it is attested by the law and the prophets) has been disclosed—
speaker: Narrator

text: namely, the righteousness of God through the faithfulness of Jesus Christ for all who believe. For there is no distinction,
speaker: Narrator

text: for all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they are justified freely by his grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: God publicly displayed him at his death as the mercy seat accessible through faith. This was to demonstrate his righteousness, because God in his forbearance had passed over the sins previously committed.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was also to demonstrate his righteousness in the present time, so that he would be just and the justifier of the one who lives because of Jesus’ faithfulness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Where, then, is boasting? It is excluded! By what principle? Of works? No, but by the principle of faith!
speaker: Narrator

text: For we consider that a person is declared righteous by faith apart from the works of the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or is God the God of the Jews only? Is he not the God of the Gentiles too? Yes, of the Gentiles too!
speaker: Narrator

text: Since God is one, he will justify the circumcised by faith and the uncircumcised through faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do we then nullify the law through faith? Absolutely not! Instead we uphold the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then shall we say that Abraham, our ancestor according to the flesh, has discovered regarding this matter?
speaker: Narrator

text: For if Abraham was declared righteous by works, he has something to boast about—but not before God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For what does the scripture say? “Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him as righteousness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now to the one who works, his pay is not credited due to grace but due to obligation.
speaker: Narrator

text: But to the one who does not work, but believes in the one who declares the ungodly righteous, his faith is credited as righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: So even David himself speaks regarding the blessedness of the man to whom God credits righteousness apart from works:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Blessed are those whose lawless deeds are forgiven, and whose sins are covered;
speaker: Narrator

text: blessed is the one against whom the Lord will never count sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Is this blessedness then for the circumcision or also for the uncircumcision? For we say, “faith was credited to Abraham as righteousness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: How then was it credited to him? Was he circumcised at the time, or not? No, he was not circumcised but uncircumcised!
speaker: Narrator

text: And he received the sign of circumcision as a seal of the righteousness that he had by faith while he was still uncircumcised, so that he would become the father of all those who believe but have never been circumcised, that they too could have righteousness credited to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he is also the father of the circumcised, who are not only circumcised, but who also walk in the footsteps of the faith that our father Abraham possessed when he was still uncircumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the promise to Abraham or to his descendants that he would inherit the world was not fulfilled through the law, but through the righteousness that comes by faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if they become heirs by the law, faith is empty and the promise is nullified.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the law brings wrath, because where there is no law there is no transgression either.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason it is by faith so that it may be by grace, with the result that the promise may be certain to all the descendants—not only to those who are under the law, but also to those who have the faith of Abraham, who is the father of us all
speaker: Narrator

text: (as it is written, “I have made you the father of many nations”). He is our father in the presence of God whom he believed—the God who makes the dead alive and summons the things that do not yet exist as though they already do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Against hope Abraham believed in hope with the result that he became the father of many nations according to the pronouncement, “so will your descendants be.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Without being weak in faith, he considered his own body as dead (because he was about 100 years old) and the deadness of Sarah’s womb.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did not waver in unbelief about the promise of God but was strengthened in faith, giving glory to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was fully convinced that what God promised he was also able to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: So indeed it was credited to Abraham as righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the statement it was credited to him was not written only for Abraham’s sake,
speaker: Narrator

text: but also for our sake, to whom it will be credited, those who believe in the one who raised Jesus our Lord from the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was given over because of our transgressions and was raised for the sake of our justification.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, since we have been declared righteous by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ,
speaker: Narrator

text: through whom we have also obtained access into this grace in which we stand, and we rejoice in the hope of God’s glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not only this, but we also rejoice in sufferings, knowing that suffering produces endurance,
speaker: Narrator

text: and endurance, character, and character, hope.
speaker: Narrator

text: And hope does not disappoint, because the love of God has been poured out in our hearts through the Holy Spirit who was given to us.
speaker: Narrator

text: For while we were still helpless, at the right time Christ died for the ungodly.
speaker: Narrator

text: (For rarely will anyone die for a righteous person, though for a good person perhaps someone might possibly dare to die.)
speaker: Narrator

text: But God demonstrates his own love for us, in that while we were still sinners, Christ died for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Much more then, because we have now been declared righteous by his blood, we will be saved through him from God’s wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if while we were enemies we were reconciled to God through the death of his Son, how much more, since we have been reconciled, will we be saved by his life?
speaker: Narrator

text: Not only this, but we also rejoice in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom we have now received this reconciliation.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, just as sin entered the world through one man and death through sin, and so death spread to all people because all sinned—
speaker: Narrator

text: for before the law was given, sin was in the world, but there is no accounting for sin when there is no law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet death reigned from Adam until Moses even over those who did not sin in the same way that Adam (who is a type of the coming one) transgressed.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the gracious gift is not like the transgression. For if the many died through the transgression of the one man, how much more did the grace of God and the gift by the grace of the one man Jesus Christ multiply to the many!
speaker: Narrator

text: And the gift is not like the one who sinned. For judgment, resulting from the one transgression, led to condemnation, but the gracious gift from the many failures led to justification.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if, by the transgression of the one man, death reigned through the one, how much more will those who receive the abundance of grace and of the gift of righteousness reign in life through the one, Jesus Christ!
speaker: Narrator

text: Consequently, just as condemnation for all people came through one transgression, so too through the one righteous act came righteousness leading to life for all people.
speaker: Narrator

text: For just as through the disobedience of the one man many were constituted sinners, so also through the obedience of one man many will be constituted righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the law came in so that the transgression may increase, but where sin increased, grace multiplied all the more,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that just as sin reigned in death, so also grace will reign through righteousness to eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: What shall we say then? Are we to remain in sin so that grace may increase?
speaker: Narrator

text: Absolutely not! How can we who died to sin still live in it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Or do you not know that as many as were baptized into Christ Jesus were baptized into his death?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore we have been buried with him through baptism into death, in order that just as Christ was raised from the dead through the glory of the Father, so we too may live a new life.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if we have become united with him in the likeness of his death, we will certainly also be united in the likeness of his resurrection.
speaker: Narrator

text: We know that our old man was crucified with him so that the body of sin would no longer dominate us, so that we would no longer be enslaved to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: (For someone who has died has been freed from sin.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if we died with Christ, we believe that we will also live with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: We know that since Christ has been raised from the dead, he is never going to die again; death no longer has mastery over him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the death he died, he died to sin once for all, but the life he lives, he lives to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you too consider yourselves dead to sin, but alive to God in Christ Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore do not let sin reign in your mortal body so that you obey its desires,
speaker: Narrator

text: and do not present your members to sin as instruments to be used for unrighteousness, but present yourselves to God as those who are alive from the dead and your members to God as instruments to be used for righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: For sin will have no mastery over you, because you are not under law but under grace.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then? Shall we sin because we are not under law but under grace? Absolutely not!
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you not know that if you present yourselves as obedient slaves, you are slaves of the one you obey, either of sin resulting in death, or obedience resulting in righteousness?
speaker: Narrator

text: But thanks be to God that though you were slaves to sin, you obeyed from the heart that pattern of teaching you were entrusted to,
speaker: Narrator

text: and having been freed from sin, you became enslaved to righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: (I am speaking in human terms because of the weakness of your flesh.) For just as you once presented your members as slaves to impurity and lawlessness leading to more lawlessness, so now present your members as slaves to righteousness leading to sanctification.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when you were slaves of sin, you were free with regard to righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: So what benefit did you then reap from those things that you are now ashamed of? For the end of those things is death.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now, freed from sin and enslaved to God, you have your benefit leading to sanctification, and the end is eternal life.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the payoff of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or do you not know, brothers and sisters (for I am speaking to those who know the law), that the law is lord over a person as long as he lives?
speaker: Narrator

text: For a married woman is bound by law to her husband as long as he lives, but if her husband dies, she is released from the law of the marriage.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, if she is joined to another man while her husband is alive, she will be called an adulteress. But if her husband dies, she is free from that law, and if she is joined to another man, she is not an adulteress.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, my brothers and sisters, you also died to the law through the body of Christ, so that you could be joined to another, to the one who was raised from the dead, to bear fruit to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when we were in the flesh, the sinful desires, aroused by the law, were active in the members of our body to bear fruit for death.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now we have been released from the law, because we have died to what controlled us, so that we may serve in the new life of the Spirit and not under the old written code.
speaker: Narrator

text: What shall we say then? Is the law sin? Absolutely not! Certainly, I would not have known sin except through the law. For indeed I would not have known what it means to desire something belonging to someone else if the law had not said, “Do not covet.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But sin, seizing the opportunity through the commandment, produced in me all kinds of wrong desires. For apart from the law, sin is dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I was once alive apart from the law, but with the coming of the commandment sin became alive
speaker: Narrator

text: and I died. So I found that the very commandment that was intended to bring life brought death!
speaker: Narrator

text: For sin, seizing the opportunity through the commandment, deceived me and through it I died.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, the law is holy, and the commandment is holy, righteous, and good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Did that which is good, then, become death to me? Absolutely not! But sin, so that it would be shown to be sin, produced death in me through what is good, so that through the commandment sin would become utterly sinful.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we know that the law is spiritual—but I am unspiritual, sold into slavery to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I don’t understand what I am doing. For I do not do what I want—instead, I do what I hate.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if I do what I don’t want, I agree that the law is good.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now it is no longer me doing it, but sin that lives in me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I know that nothing good lives in me, that is, in my flesh. For I want to do the good, but I cannot do it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I do not do the good I want, but I do the very evil I do not want!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if I do what I do not want, it is no longer me doing it but sin that lives in me.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, I find the law that when I want to do good, evil is present with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I delight in the law of God in my inner being.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I see a different law in my members waging war against the law of my mind and making me captive to the law of sin that is in my members.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wretched man that I am! Who will rescue me from this body of death?
speaker: Narrator

text: Thanks be to God through Jesus Christ our Lord! So then, I myself serve the law of God with my mind, but with my flesh I serve the law of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is therefore now no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the law of the life-giving Spirit in Christ Jesus has set you free from the law of sin and death.
speaker: Narrator

text: For God achieved what the law could not do because it was weakened through the flesh. By sending his own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh and concerning sin, he condemned sin in the flesh,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that the righteous requirement of the law may be fulfilled in us, who do not walk according to the flesh but according to the Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: For those who live according to the flesh have their outlook shaped by the things of the flesh, but those who live according to the Spirit have their outlook shaped by the things of the Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the outlook of the flesh is death, but the outlook of the Spirit is life and peace,
speaker: Narrator

text: because the outlook of the flesh is hostile to God, for it does not submit to the law of God, nor is it able to do so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who are in the flesh cannot please God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You, however, are not in the flesh but in the Spirit, if indeed the Spirit of God lives in you. Now if anyone does not have the Spirit of Christ, this person does not belong to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if Christ is in you, your body is dead because of sin, but the Spirit is your life because of righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover if the Spirit of the one who raised Jesus from the dead lives in you, the one who raised Christ from the dead will also make your mortal bodies alive through his Spirit who lives in you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, brothers and sisters, we are under obligation, not to the flesh, to live according to the flesh
speaker: Narrator

text: (for if you live according to the flesh, you will die), but if by the Spirit you put to death the deeds of the body you will live.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all who are led by the Spirit of God are the sons of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you did not receive the spirit of slavery leading again to fear, but you received the Spirit of adoption, by whom we cry, “Abba, Father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Spirit himself bears witness to our spirit that we are God’s children.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if children, then heirs (namely, heirs of God and also fellow heirs with Christ)—if indeed we suffer with him so we may also be glorified with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I consider that our present sufferings cannot even be compared to the coming glory that will be revealed to us.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the creation eagerly waits for the revelation of the sons of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the creation was subjected to futility—not willingly but because of God who subjected it—in hope
speaker: Narrator

text: that the creation itself will also be set free from the bondage of decay into the glorious freedom of God’s children.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we know that the whole creation groans and suffers together until now.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not only this, but we ourselves also, who have the firstfruits of the Spirit, groan inwardly as we eagerly await our adoption, the redemption of our bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: For in hope we were saved. Now hope that is seen is not hope, because who hopes for what he sees?
speaker: Narrator

text: But if we hope for what we do not see, we eagerly wait for it with endurance.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, the Spirit helps us in our weakness, for we do not know how we should pray, but the Spirit himself intercedes for us with inexpressible groanings.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he who searches our hearts knows the mind of the Spirit, because the Spirit intercedes on behalf of the saints according to God’s will.
speaker: Narrator

text: And we know that all things work together for good for those who love God, who are called according to his purpose,
speaker: Narrator

text: because those whom he foreknew he also predestined to be conformed to the image of his Son, that his Son would be the firstborn among many brothers and sisters.
speaker: Narrator

text: And those he predestined, he also called; and those he called, he also justified; and those he justified, he also glorified.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then shall we say about these things? If God is for us, who can be against us?
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, he who did not spare his own Son, but gave him up for us all—how will he not also, along with him, freely give us all things?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who will bring any charge against God’s elect? It is God who justifies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is the one who will condemn? Christ is the one who died (and more than that, he was raised), who is at the right hand of God, and who also is interceding for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who will separate us from the love of Christ? Will trouble, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or danger, or sword?
speaker: Narrator

text: As it is written, “For your sake we encounter death all day long; we were considered as sheep to be slaughtered.”
speaker: Narrator

text: No, in all these things we have complete victory through him who loved us!
speaker: Narrator

text: For I am convinced that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor heavenly rulers, nor things that are present, nor things to come, nor powers,
speaker: Narrator

text: nor height, nor depth, nor anything else in creation will be able to separate us from the love of God in Christ Jesus our Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am telling the truth in Christ (I am not lying!), for my conscience assures me in the Holy Spirit—
speaker: Narrator

text: I have great sorrow and unceasing anguish in my heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I could wish that I myself were accursed—cut off from Christ—for the sake of my people, my fellow countrymen,
speaker: Narrator

text: who are Israelites. To them belong the adoption as sons, the glory, the covenants, the giving of the law, the temple worship, and the promises.
speaker: Narrator

text: To them belong the patriarchs, and from them, by human descent, came the Christ, who is God over all, blessed forever! Amen.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not as though the word of God had failed. For not all those who are descended from Israel are truly Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: nor are all the children Abraham’s true descendants; rather “through Isaac will your descendants be counted.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This means it is not the children of the flesh who are the children of God; rather, the children of promise are counted as descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this is what the promise declared: “About a year from now I will return and Sarah will have a son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Not only that, but when Rebekah had conceived children by one man, our ancestor Isaac—
speaker: Narrator

text: even before they were born or had done anything good or bad (so that God’s purpose in election would stand, not by works but by his calling)—
speaker: Narrator

text: it was said to her, “The older will serve the younger,”
speaker: Narrator

text: just as it is written: “Jacob I loved, but Esau I hated.”
speaker: Narrator

text: What shall we say then? Is there injustice with God? Absolutely not!
speaker: Narrator

text: For he says to Moses: “I will have mercy on whom I have mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I have compassion.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, it does not depend on human desire or exertion, but on God who shows mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the scripture says to Pharaoh: “For this very purpose I have raised you up, that I may demonstrate my power in you, and that my name may be proclaimed in all the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, God has mercy on whom he chooses to have mercy, and he hardens whom he chooses to harden.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will say to me then, “Why does he still find fault? For who has ever resisted his will?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But who indeed are you—a mere human being—to talk back to God? Does what is molded say to the molder, “Why have you made me like this?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Has the potter no right to make from the same lump of clay one vessel for special use and another for ordinary use?
speaker: Narrator

text: But what if God, willing to demonstrate his wrath and to make known his power, has endured with much patience the objects of wrath prepared for destruction?
speaker: Narrator

text: And what if he is willing to make known the wealth of his glory on the objects of mercy that he has prepared beforehand for glory—
speaker: Narrator

text: even us, whom he has called, not only from the Jews but also from the Gentiles?
speaker: Narrator

text:
As he also says in Hosea:
“I will call those who were not my people, ‘My people,’ and I will call her who was unloved, ‘My beloved.’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And in the very place where it was said to them, ‘You are not my people,’
there they will be called ‘sons of the living God.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Isaiah cries out on behalf of Israel, “Though the number of the children of Israel are as the sand of the sea, only the remnant will be saved,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the Lord will execute his sentence on the earth completely and quickly.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Just as Isaiah predicted,
“If the Lord of Heaven’s Armies had not left us descendants,
we would have become like Sodom,
and we would have resembled Gomorrah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: What shall we say then?—that the Gentiles who did not pursue righteousness obtained it, that is, a righteousness that is by faith,
speaker: Narrator

text: but Israel even though pursuing a law of righteousness did not attain it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why not? Because they pursued it not by faith but (as if it were possible) by works. They stumbled over the stumbling stone,
speaker: Narrator

text:
just as it is written,
“Look, I am laying in Zion a stone that will cause people to stumble
and a rock that will make them fall,
yet the one who believes in him will not be put to shame.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Brothers and sisters, my heart’s desire and prayer to God on behalf of my fellow Israelites is for their salvation.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I can testify that they are zealous for God, but their zeal is not in line with the truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: For ignoring the righteousness that comes from God, and seeking instead to establish their own righteousness, they did not submit to God’s righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Christ is the end of the law, with the result that there is righteousness for everyone who believes.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Moses writes about the righteousness that is by the law: “The one who does these things will live by them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the righteousness that is by faith says: “Do not say in your heart, ‘Who will ascend into heaven?’” (that is, to bring Christ down)
speaker: Narrator

text: or “Who will descend into the abyss?” (that is, to bring Christ up from the dead).
speaker: Narrator

text: But what does it say? “The word is near you, in your mouth and in your heart” (that is, the word of faith that we preach),
speaker: Narrator

text: because if you confess with your mouth that Jesus is Lord and believe in your heart that God raised him from the dead, you will be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: For with the heart one believes and thus has righteousness and with the mouth one confesses and thus has salvation.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the scripture says, “Everyone who believes in him will not be put to shame.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For there is no distinction between the Jew and the Greek, for the same Lord is Lord of all, who richly blesses all who call on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For everyone who calls on the name of the Lord will be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: How are they to call on one they have not believed in? And how are they to believe in one they have not heard of? And how are they to hear without someone preaching to them?
speaker: Narrator

text: And how are they to preach unless they are sent? As it is written, “How timely is the arrival of those who proclaim the good news.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But not all have obeyed the good news, for Isaiah says, “Lord, who has believed our report?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Consequently faith comes from what is heard, and what is heard comes through the preached word of Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I ask, have they not heard? Yes, they have: Their voice has gone out to all the earth, and their words to the ends of the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: But again I ask, didn’t Israel understand? First Moses says, “I will make you jealous by those who are not a nation; with a senseless nation I will provoke you to anger.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Isaiah is even bold enough to say, “I was found by those who did not seek me; I became well known to those who did not ask for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But about Israel he says, “All day long I held out my hands to this disobedient and stubborn people!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I ask, God has not rejected his people, has he? Absolutely not! For I too am an Israelite, a descendant of Abraham, from the tribe of Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: God has not rejected his people whom he foreknew! Do you not know what the scripture says about Elijah, how he pleads with God against Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: “Lord, they have killed your prophets, they have demolished your altars; I alone am left and they are seeking my life!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But what was the divine response to him? “I have kept for myself 7,000 people who have not bent the knee to Baal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So in the same way at the present time there is a remnant chosen by grace.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if it is by grace, it is no longer by works, otherwise grace would no longer be grace.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then? Israel failed to obtain what it was diligently seeking, but the elect obtained it. The rest were hardened,
speaker: Narrator

text:
as it is written,
“God gave them a spirit of stupor,
eyes that would not see and ears that would not hear,
to this very day.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
let their eyes be darkened so that they may not see,
and make their backs bend continually.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I ask then, they did not stumble into an irrevocable fall, did they? Absolutely not! But by their transgression salvation has come to the Gentiles, to make Israel jealous.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if their transgression means riches for the world and their defeat means riches for the Gentiles, how much more will their full restoration bring?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I am speaking to you Gentiles. Seeing that I am an apostle to the Gentiles, I magnify my ministry,
speaker: Narrator

text: if somehow I could provoke my people to jealousy and save some of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if their rejection is the reconciliation of the world, what will their acceptance be but life from the dead?
speaker: Narrator

text: If the first portion of the dough offered is holy, then the whole batch is holy, and if the root is holy, so too are the branches.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if some of the branches were broken off, and you, a wild olive shoot, were grafted in among them and participated in the richness of the olive root,
speaker: Narrator

text: do not boast over the branches. But if you boast, remember that you do not support the root, but the root supports you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will say, “The branches were broken off so that I could be grafted in.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Granted! They were broken off because of their unbelief, but you stand by faith. Do not be arrogant, but fear!
speaker: Narrator

text: For if God did not spare the natural branches, perhaps he will not spare you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Notice therefore the kindness and harshness of God—harshness toward those who have fallen, but God’s kindness toward you, provided you continue in his kindness; otherwise you also will be cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text: And even they—if they do not continue in their unbelief—will be grafted in, for God is able to graft them in again.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if you were cut off from what is by nature a wild olive tree, and grafted, contrary to nature, into a cultivated olive tree, how much more will these natural branches be grafted back into their own olive tree?
speaker: Narrator

text: For I do not want you to be ignorant of this mystery, brothers and sisters, so that you may not be conceited: A partial hardening has happened to Israel until the full number of the Gentiles has come in.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
And this is my covenant with them,
when I take away their sins.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In regard to the gospel they are enemies for your sake, but in regard to election they are dearly loved for the sake of the fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the gifts and the call of God are irrevocable.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as you were formerly disobedient to God, but have now received mercy due to their disobedience,
speaker: Narrator

text: so they too have now been disobedient in order that, by the mercy shown to you, they too may now receive mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text: For God has consigned all people to disobedience so that he may show mercy to them all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Oh, the depth of the riches and wisdom and knowledge of God! How unsearchable are his judgments and how unfathomable his ways!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For who has known the mind of the Lord,
or who has been his counselor?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or who has first given to God,
that God needs to repay him?
speaker: Narrator

text: For from him and through him and to him are all things. To him be glory forever! Amen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I exhort you, brothers and sisters, by the mercies of God, to present your bodies as a sacrifice—alive, holy, and pleasing to God—which is your reasonable service.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be conformed to this present world, but be transformed by the renewing of your mind, so that you may test and approve what is the will of God—what is good and well-pleasing and perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: For by the grace given to me I say to every one of you not to think more highly of yourself than you ought to think, but to think with sober discernment, as God has distributed to each of you a measure of faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: For just as in one body we have many members, and not all the members serve the same function,
speaker: Narrator

text: so we who are many are one body in Christ, and individually we are members who belong to one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: And we have different gifts according to the grace given to us. If the gift is prophecy, that individual must use it in proportion to his faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it is service, he must serve; if it is teaching, he must teach;
speaker: Narrator

text: if it is exhortation, he must exhort; if it is contributing, he must do so with sincerity; if it is leadership, he must do so with diligence; if it is showing mercy, he must do so with cheerfulness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Love must be without hypocrisy. Abhor what is evil, cling to what is good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be devoted to one another with mutual love, showing eagerness in honoring one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not lag in zeal, be enthusiastic in spirit, serve the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rejoice in hope, endure in suffering, persist in prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Contribute to the needs of the saints, pursue hospitality.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bless those who persecute you, bless and do not curse.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rejoice with those who rejoice, weep with those who weep.
speaker: Narrator

text: Live in harmony with one another; do not be haughty but associate with the lowly. Do not be conceited.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not repay anyone evil for evil; consider what is good before all people.
speaker: Narrator

text: If possible, so far as it depends on you, live peaceably with all people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not avenge yourselves, dear friends, but give place to God’s wrath, for it is written, “Vengeance is mine, I will repay,” says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rather, if your enemy is hungry, feed him; if he is thirsty, give him a drink; for in doing this you will be heaping burning coals on his head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be overcome by evil, but overcome evil with good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let every person be subject to the governing authorities. For there is no authority except by God’s appointment, and the authorities that exist have been instituted by God.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the person who resists such authority resists the ordinance of God, and those who resist will incur judgment
speaker: Narrator

text: (for rulers cause no fear for good conduct but for bad). Do you desire not to fear authority? Do good and you will receive its commendation
speaker: Narrator

text: because it is God’s servant for your well-being. But be afraid if you do wrong because government does not bear the sword for nothing. It is God’s servant to administer punishment on the person who does wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore it is necessary to be in subjection, not only because of the wrath of the authorities but also because of your conscience.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason you also pay taxes, for the authorities are God’s servants devoted to governing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pay everyone what is owed: taxes to whom taxes are due, revenue to whom revenue is due, respect to whom respect is due, honor to whom honor is due.
speaker: Narrator

text: Owe no one anything, except to love one another, for the one who loves his neighbor has fulfilled the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the commandments, “Do not commit adultery, do not murder, do not steal, do not covet,” (and if there is any other commandment) are summed up in this, “Love your neighbor as yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Love does no wrong to a neighbor. Therefore love is the fulfillment of the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: And do this because we know the time, that it is already the hour for us to awake from sleep, for our salvation is now nearer than when we became believers.
speaker: Narrator

text: The night has advanced toward dawn; the day is near. So then we must lay aside the works of darkness, and put on the weapons of light.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us live decently as in the daytime, not in carousing and drunkenness, not in sexual immorality and sensuality, not in discord and jealousy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, put on the Lord Jesus Christ, and make no provision for the flesh to arouse its desires.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now receive the one who is weak in the faith, and do not have disputes over differing opinions.
speaker: Narrator

text: One person believes in eating everything, but the weak person eats only vegetables.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who eats everything must not despise the one who does not, and the one who abstains must not judge the one who eats everything, for God has accepted him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who are you to pass judgment on another’s servant? Before his own master he stands or falls. And he will stand, for the Lord is able to make him stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: One person regards one day holier than other days, and another regards them all alike. Each must be fully convinced in his own mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who observes the day does it for the Lord. The one who eats, eats for the Lord because he gives thanks to God, and the one who abstains from eating abstains for the Lord, and he gives thanks to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For none of us lives for himself and none dies for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: If we live, we live for the Lord; if we die, we die for the Lord. Therefore, whether we live or die, we are the Lord’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason Christ died and returned to life, so that he may be the Lord of both the dead and the living.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you who eat vegetables only—why do you judge your brother or sister? And you who eat everything—why do you despise your brother or sister? For we will all stand before the judgment seat of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it is written, “As I live, says the Lord, every knee will bow to me, and every tongue will give praise to God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, each of us will give an account of himself to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore we must not pass judgment on one another, but rather determine never to place an obstacle or a trap before a brother or sister.
speaker: Narrator

text: I know and am convinced in the Lord Jesus that there is nothing unclean in itself; still, it is unclean to the one who considers it unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if your brother or sister is distressed because of what you eat, you are no longer walking in love. Do not destroy by your food someone for whom Christ died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore do not let what you consider good be spoken of as evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the kingdom of God does not consist of food and drink, but righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the one who serves Christ in this way is pleasing to God and approved by people.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, let us pursue what makes for peace and for building up one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not destroy the work of God for the sake of food. For although all things are clean, it is wrong to cause anyone to stumble by what you eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is good not to eat meat or drink wine or to do anything that causes your brother to stumble.
speaker: Narrator

text: The faith you have, keep to yourself before God. Blessed is the one who does not judge himself by what he approves.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the man who doubts is condemned if he eats, because he does not do so from faith, and whatever is not from faith is sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we who are strong ought to bear with the failings of the weak, and not just please ourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let each of us please his neighbor for his good to build him up.
speaker: Narrator

text: For even Christ did not please himself, but just as it is written, “The insults of those who insult you have fallen on me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For everything that was written in former times was written for our instruction, so that through endurance and through encouragement of the scriptures we may have hope.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now may the God of endurance and comfort give you unity with one another in accordance with Christ Jesus,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that together you may with one voice glorify the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Receive one another, then, just as Christ also received you, to God’s glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I tell you that Christ has become a servant of the circumcised on behalf of God’s truth to confirm the promises made to the fathers,
speaker: Narrator

text: and thus the Gentiles glorify God for his mercy. As it is written, “Because of this I will confess you among the Gentiles, and I will sing praises to your name.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And again it says: “Rejoice, O Gentiles, with his people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And again, “Praise the Lord all you Gentiles, and let all the peoples praise him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And again Isaiah says, “The root of Jesse will come, and the one who rises to rule over the Gentiles, in him will the Gentiles hope.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now may the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace as you believe in him, so that you may abound in hope by the power of the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I myself am fully convinced about you, my brothers and sisters, that you yourselves are full of goodness, filled with all knowledge, and able to instruct one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I have written more boldly to you on some points so as to remind you, because of the grace given to me by God
speaker: Narrator

text: to be a minister of Christ Jesus to the Gentiles. I serve the gospel of God like a priest, so that the Gentiles may become an acceptable offering, sanctified by the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I boast in Christ Jesus about the things that pertain to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I will not dare to speak of anything except what Christ has accomplished through me in order to bring about the obedience of the Gentiles, by word and deed,
speaker: Narrator

text: in the power of signs and wonders, in the power of the Spirit of God. So from Jerusalem even as far as Illyricum I have fully preached the gospel of Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in this way I desire to preach where Christ has not been named, so as not to build on another person’s foundation,
speaker: Narrator

text: but as it is written: “Those who were not told about him will see, and those who have not heard will understand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the reason I was often hindered from coming to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now there is nothing more to keep me in these regions, and I have for many years desired to come to you
speaker: Narrator

text: when I go to Spain. For I hope to visit you when I pass through and that you will help me on my journey there, after I have enjoyed your company for a while.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now I go to Jerusalem to minister to the saints.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Macedonia and Achaia are pleased to make some contribution for the poor among the saints in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they were pleased to do this, and indeed they are indebted to the Jerusalem saints. For if the Gentiles have shared in their spiritual things, they are obligated also to minister to them in material things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore after I have completed this and have safely delivered this bounty to them, I will set out for Spain by way of you,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I know that when I come to you I will come in the fullness of Christ’s blessing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I urge you, brothers and sisters, through our Lord Jesus Christ and through the love of the Spirit, to join fervently with me in prayer to God on my behalf.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pray that I may be rescued from those who are disobedient in Judea and that my ministry in Jerusalem may be acceptable to the saints,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that by God’s will I may come to you with joy and be refreshed in your company.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now may the God of peace be with all of you. Amen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I commend to you our sister Phoebe, who is a servant of the church in Cenchrea,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that you may welcome her in the Lord in a way worthy of the saints and provide her with whatever help she may need from you, for she has been a great help to many, including me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Prisca and Aquila, my fellow workers in Christ Jesus,
speaker: Narrator

text: who risked their own necks for my life. Not only I, but all the churches of the Gentiles are grateful to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also greet the church in their house. Greet my dear friend Epenetus, who was the first convert to Christ in the province of Asia.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Mary, who has worked very hard for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Andronicus and Junia, my compatriots and my fellow prisoners. They are well known to the apostles, and they were in Christ before me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Ampliatus, my dear friend in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Urbanus, our fellow worker in Christ, and my good friend Stachys.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Apelles, who is approved in Christ. Greet those who belong to the household of Aristobulus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Herodion, my compatriot. Greet those in the household of Narcissus who are in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Tryphena and Tryphosa, laborers in the Lord. Greet my dear friend Persis, who has worked hard in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Rufus, chosen in the Lord, and his mother who was also a mother to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Asyncritus, Phlegon, Hermes, Patrobas, Hermas, and the brothers and sisters with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Philologus and Julia, Nereus and his sister, and Olympas, and all the believers who are with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet one another with a holy kiss. All the churches of Christ greet you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I urge you, brothers and sisters, to watch out for those who create dissensions and obstacles contrary to the teaching that you learned. Avoid them!
speaker: Narrator

text: For these are the kind who do not serve our Lord Christ, but their own appetites. By their smooth talk and flattery they deceive the minds of the naive.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your obedience is known to all and thus I rejoice over you. But I want you to be wise in what is good and innocent in what is evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: The God of peace will quickly crush Satan under your feet. The grace of our Lord Jesus be with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Timothy, my fellow worker, greets you; so do Lucius, Jason, and Sosipater, my compatriots.
speaker: Narrator

text: I, Tertius, who am writing this letter, greet you in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gaius, who is host to me and to the whole church, greets you. Erastus the city treasurer and our brother Quartus greet you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now to him who is able to strengthen you according to my gospel and the proclamation of Jesus Christ, according to the revelation of the mystery that had been kept secret for long ages,
speaker: Narrator

text: but now is disclosed, and through the prophetic scriptures has been made known to all the nations, according to the command of the eternal God, to bring about the obedience of faith—
speaker: Narrator

text: to the only wise God, through Jesus Christ, be glory forever! Amen.
speaker: Narrator
